#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=THE FATALIST
#Text=I ONCE happened to spend a couple of weeks in a Cossack village on our left flank .
#Text=A battalion of infantry was stationed there ; and it was the custom of the officers to meet at each other ’s quarters in turn and play cards in the evening .
#Text=On one occasion -- it was at Major S -- --‘s -- finding our game of Boston not sufficiently absorbing , we threw the cards under the table and sat on for a long time , talking .
#Text=The conversation , for once in a way , was interesting .
#Text=The subject was the Mussulman tradition that a man ’s fate is written in heaven , and we discussed the fact that it was gaining many votaries , even amongst our own countrymen .
#Text=Each of us related various extraordinary occurrences , pro or contra .
#Text=“ What you have been saying , gentlemen , proves nothing , ” said the old major .
#Text=“ I presume there is not one of you who has actually been a witness of the strange events which you are citing in support of your opinions ? ”
#Text=“ Not one , of course , ” said many of the guests .
#Text=“ But we have heard of them from trustworthy people . ” ...
#Text=“ It is all nonsense ! ” someone said .
#Text=“ Where are the trustworthy people who have seen the Register in which the appointed hour of our death is recorded ? ...
#Text=And if predestination really exists , why are free will and reason granted us ?
#Text=Why are we obliged to render an account of our actions ? ”
#Text=At that moment an officer who was sitting in a corner of the room stood up , and , coming slowly to the table , surveyed us all with a quiet and solemn glance .
#Text=He was a native of Servia , as was evident from his name .
#Text=The outward appearance of Lieutenant Vulich was quite in keeping with his character .

#Text=His height , swarthy complexion , black hair , piercing black eyes , large but straight nose -- an attribute of his nation -- and the cold and melancholy smile which ever hovered around his lips , all seemed to concur in lending him the appearance of a man apart , incapable of reciprocating the thoughts and passions of those whom fate gave him for companions .

#Text=He was brave ; talked little , but sharply ; confided his thoughts and family secrets to no one ; drank hardly a drop of wine ; and never dangled after the young Cossack girls , whose charm it is difficult to realise without having seen them .
#Text=It was said , however , that the colonel ’s wife was not indifferent to those expressive eyes of his ; but he was seriously angry if any hint on the subject was made .
#Text=There was only one passion which he did not conceal -- the passion for gambling .
#Text=At the green table he would become oblivious of everything .
#Text=He usually lost , but his constant ill success only aroused his obstinacy .
#Text=It was related that , on one occasion , during a nocturnal expedition , he was keeping the bank on a pillow , and had a terrific run of luck .
#Text=Suddenly shots rang out .
#Text=The alarm was sounded ; all but Vulich jumped up and rushed to arms .
#Text=“ Stake , va banque ! ” he cried to one of the most ardent gamblers .
#Text=“ Seven , ” the latter answered as he hurried off .
#Text=Notwithstanding the general confusion , Vulich calmly finished the deal -- seven was the card .
#Text=By the time he reached the cordon a violent fusillade was in progress .
#Text=Vulich did not trouble himself about the bullets or the sabres of the Chechenes , but sought for the lucky gambler .

#Text=“ Seven it was ! ” he cried out , as at length he perceived him in the cordon of skirmishers who were beginning to dislodge the enemy from the wood ; and going up to him , he drew out his purse and pocket-book and handed them to the winner , notwithstanding the latter ’s objections on the score of the inconvenience of the payment .
#Text=That unpleasant duty discharged , Vulich dashed forward , carried the soldiers along after him , and , to the very end of the affair , fought the Chechenes with the utmost coolness .
#Text=When Lieutenant Vulich came up to the table , we all became silent , expecting to hear , as usual , something original .
#Text=“ Gentlemen ! ” he said -- and his voice was quiet though lower in tone than usual -- “gentlemen , what is the good of futile discussions ?
#Text=You wish for proofs ?
#Text=I propose that we try the experiment on ourselves : whether a man can of his own accord dispose of his life , or whether the fateful moment is appointed beforehand for each of us .
#Text=Who is agreeable ? ”
#Text=“ Not I. Not I , ” came from all sides .
#Text=“ There ’s a queer fellow for you !
#Text=He does get strange ideas into his head ! ”
#Text=“ I propose a wager , ” I said in jest .
#Text=“ What sort of wager ? ”
#Text=“ I maintain that there is no such thing as predestination , ” I said , scattering on the table a score or so of ducats -- all I had in my pocket .
#Text=“ Done , ” answered Vulich in a hollow voice .
#Text=“ Major , you will be judge .
#Text=Here are fifteen ducats , the remaining five you owe me , kindly add them to the others . ”
#Text=“ Very well , ” said the major ;
#Text=“ though , indeed , I do not understand what is the question at issue and how you will decide it ! ”
#Text=Without a word Vulich went into the major ’s bedroom , and we followed him .
#Text=He went up to the wall on which the major ’s weapons were hanging , and took down at random one of the pistols -- of which there were several of different calibres .
#Text=We were still in the dark as to what he meant to do .
#Text=But , when he cocked the pistol and sprinkled powder in the pan , several of the officers , crying out in spite of themselves , seized him by the arms .
